digest.editor_note: Fellow Humans, the macro picture today is a tug-of-war between sticky inflation and fragile confidence. Goolsbee is pumping the brakes on rate cuts, consumers are barely off the mat after January's confidence collapse, and Russia's war economy is being cited as a slow-motion structural implosion. The Fed patience trade is back, and markets are pricing in discomfort. — Ed.

sentiment.label: Cautious
sentiment.context: Fed officials signaling a hold on cuts, sub-80 consumer expectations for 13 consecutive months, and a deteriorating Russia macro backdrop all point to a market sitting on its hands.

stories.headline: Fed's Goolsbee signals rate-cut pause as inflation remains 'not good enough'
stories.body: Chicago Fed President Austan Goolsbee said Tuesday he wants to see further inflation progress before supporting additional rate cuts, adding that a recent tariff court ruling could help ease price pressures. The comment reinforces the Fed's wait-and-see posture heading into spring, with markets already pushing back rate-cut expectations. For rate-sensitive assets, this is another reminder that the easing cycle is not on autopilot.

stories.headline: US consumer confidence edges up to 91.2 in February but recession warning gauge stays below 80 for 13th straight month
stories.body: The Conference Board's consumer confidence index rose to 91.2 from a revised 89 in January, offering modest relief after a sharp drop. However, the expectations sub-index — a recession leading indicator — rose only to 72, still well below the critical 80 threshold for the 13th consecutive month. Trade and politics are top of mind for respondents, while the labor market added just 584,000 jobs in all of 2025, roughly one-quarter of 2024's pace.

stories.source: The New York Times via Slashdot
stories.headline: Russia's war-remade economy is sowing the seeds of a long-term structural slump
stories.body: A wave of analysis — from the NYT to Reuters Breakingviews to The Economist — converges on the same conclusion: Russia's pivot to a war footing has inflated short-term activity while gutting long-term productive capacity. Elevated military spending is crowding out investment, labor shortages are deepening, and inflation is running hot. The longer the war continues, the steeper the eventual economic unwind.

stories.headline: Veris Residential agrees to $3.4B take-private deal led by Affinius Capital
stories.body: The multifamily REIT — formerly Mack-Cali Realty — has agreed to be acquired by an Affinius Capital and Vista Hill Partners consortium in an all-cash deal expected to close in Q2 2026, pending shareholder approval. Financing includes a $2.08 billion senior secured bridge loan. The deal caps a five-year pivot away from suburban office assets and validates the multifamily thesis in the current rate environment.

stories.headline: Bear case on RXO: Truck broker may be near zero cash, raising solvency concerns
stories.body: Analyst Keith Dalrymple via DF Research argues RXO, Inc. faces a severe liquidity crisis after Q4 2025, estimating cash balances have likely hit zero following negative free cash flow of roughly $25 million. Gross margins are estimated to have declined 130–225 basis points sequentially as spot freight rates surged faster than RXO could reprice contracts, with EBITDA falling well short of management's $20–30 million guidance. Accounting opacity — including the abrupt departure of the Chief Accounting Officer — adds another layer of concern to an already fragile balance sheet.

stories.headline: Waymo launches commercial driverless service in Houston, Dallas, and San Antonio
stories.body: Alphabet's Waymo began no-safety-driver robotaxi service Tuesday in Texas's three largest cities, each initially covering 25 to 60 square miles. The rollout advances the company's target of entering more than 20 cities in 2026, despite New York Governor Kathy Hochul pulling a proposal last week to allow driverless rides in the state. Avis Budget Group is set to take over Dallas fleet management later in the year under a previously disclosed deal.

stories.headline: Indian banks face narrowing margins as deposits migrate to mutual funds, equities, and gold
stories.body: A structural shift is underway in Indian banking as digitally savvy retail depositors move savings into higher-yielding alternatives, forcing banks to replace cheap retail deposits with expensive wholesale funding at rates of 7.5% or more, compressing net interest margins. Physical cash withdrawals surged to ₹4.4 trillion in the 14 months to January 2026 — three times the prior year's pace — and RBI dollar-selling operations are permanently removing rupee liquidity. The asset-liability mismatch risk is prompting calls for a fundamental recalibration of the Indian banking business model.
